document_title: Chronic heart failure: Causes, symptoms and diagnosis
subsection_content:
Diagnosis is usually based on a person's medical history, a physical exam, and certain laboratory tests, including:
Echocardiography: This method uses high-frequency sound waves to examine heart functions. This is considered the most important tool in diagnosing heart failure.; Electrocardiogram (ECG): Used to test and record heart rhythm and electrical activity.; Chest X-ray: Can provide doctors with images of the heart and fluid buildup, if present; Blood test: To measure BNP or NT-proBNP biomarker levels. Both tend to be elevated in people with heart failure.
In some cases, other methods, such as urine tests and MRI scans, may also be used.
